gave as his reason for quitting the

suited for Gas Engineering, the
course that he was pursuing. He
further stated that he desired to
"go out on his own" for a short
time, at least.

MUSICAL CLUB TO
VISIT CHAMBERSBURG
Osmar P. Steinwald, student director of the Musical
Club, recently announced that
the combined clubs will take
a post-season trip to Hagerstown and Chambersburg the
week following the home concert, which is to be held Feb.
24.
One of the two concerts
held is to be given at Wilson
College, Steinwald announced.

THE USELESSNESS OF ENGLISH LITERATURE
EXAMINATIONS
The inefficacy of the very great majority of college examinations as indices of what a student gains from a course has been
asserted so many times that it is almost an axiom. There are few
instructors who woudl maintain that they are capable of framing
an examination-which really does what it purports to do. Nevertheless, in the absence of any practical substitute, in large classes
particularly, every American college has its two or three examination periods a year.
The chances of giving a fair examination vary, however, in
different courses. Dr. Barnett, .for example, is known to give a
comprehensive examination which is usually a good gauge of the
student's mastery of the subject. In the subjects he teaches it
seems to be possible to do this, and moreover; to grade the students
with accuracy.
In certain other subjects, however, notably English Literature,
an examination which will really give the instructor an idea of the
student's knowledge and appreciation of the course is almost impossible. And if it is a difficult task to draw up an examination,
it is about fifty times that difficult to grade one. Is there any
man alive who believes that a professor of English Literature
can determine whether a student's work merits an 8.0 or an 8.5?
Or.does anyone even believe, truthfully, that a professor can often
tell, from the result of quizzes and examinations, the difference
between a 7.0 and an 8.0, or an 8.0 and a 9.0? Yes, he can quote
six words from a poem or a play and ask the student to identify
the quoted line as to author, work, and context; either the student knows, or does not know. Or he can ask the student, on the
other hand, what a certain poet meant in a certain one of his
sonnets; if the poor student doesn't happen to remember that particular sonnet, down goes his mark! Again, there may be a
question on what Matthew Arnold thinks about Crabbe. One
of the most misleading questions, from the point of view of the
possible satisfactoriness of the answer, is the one which asks a
student to describe, often in detail, some lyrical poem, such as an
elegy, an ode, or a love lyric. It is perfectly obvious that the
quality of the answers to most such questions depends in a large
degree upon two factors, neither of which is an accurate indication of the student's real appreciation of the literature he has
read. One is the retentiveness of the memory, and the other is
the student's relative powers of articulation.
The former is, logically, an anomaly. It is an accepted fact
that many students are capable of remembering, for two or three
days, details of a very large number of poems which they will
forget within a week after the examination. The latter objection
depends upon what is to be recognized as the purpose of literature
courses. If the purpose of a literature course be to awaken an
interest in good literature by bringing the student into contact
with it, the fact that he cannot express himself as glibly as his
classmate does not indicate tha.t his appreciation is any the less.
And even if part of the purpose 'of such courses is to develop
literary expression on the part of the student himself, making him
write down from memory the results of much cramming is hardly
the way to accomplish the end.
In the case of courses in English Literature there is a definite
alternate to an examination—the term paper. Such papers,
carefully outlined by the instructor so as to cover fully the scope
of the semester's work, would serve a far better purpose than an
examination for which a student stuffs his head for a week in
advance. The writing of a comprehensive paper would not only
make the student much more familiar wth the literature itself, but
would develop the student's powers of expression. He will remember much more as the result of this work than he will from having
studied for an examination.
Few people will deny the validity of this argument. This is no
essay written for the purpose of filling space: we believe that
examinations in English Literature are useless and unfair. We
believe that if the English Department should abolish examinations
at the end of the next semester and substitute in their place comprehensive term papers written under the general supervision of
the instructors, the men taking literature courses will derive far
greater benefit from those courses. Why not give the scheme a
try?

Contrary to the usual opinions
advanced by our demon statisticians,
the comptroller of the University
of Southern California calmly informs us that only at that institution men require more money to go
to college than women. The average man's annual expenditure for
clothes is estimated at between $110
to $400, while a co-ed's attire costs
only about $95 to $300. In recreation and social activities the college
man takes first place, spending from
$75 to $500, while the woman's expenditure in this line. is only from
$25 to $75.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS'NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 7. 1928

DORM DOINGS
Several changes. have been made
in the resident roll following the
first semester: —There is always a
long list of students desiring to enter the Dormitory and the few vacant rooms were quickly occupied.
Many residents have changed their
rooms and one awakes to find that
he has a whole new set of neighbors.
Although the undergraduate residents were affected more by midyears than the graduates, even they
have been less noisy than usual. The
Dormitory was practically deserted
over the week-end and not all of the
residents have returned yet. In another week or more mid-years will
be history and the residents will re"lye their activities on a greater
scale than before.

broken ones can be replaced. It
doesn't seem wise to replace them
until after the snow is well exhausted.
It is difficult to appreciate the
beauty of the campus, cloaked in
its white mantle, after tramping
through the mud puddle in front of
the Dormitory. When about five or
six residents emerge from the puddle at once it sounds' like a barrage,
as a result of their kicking to remove the mud from their knees, at
least. This particular puddle has
resisted drainage for five years.

A Marvel of National Defense
From this 23'-acre deck, Uncle
Sam's battle planes can now leap
into action—sure of a landing
place on their return, though a
thousand miles from shore.
This marvel of national defense
was accomplished and duplicated
—when the airplane carrier, U.S.S.
Saratoga, and her sister ship, U.S.S.
Lexington, were completely
electrified.
In each, four General Electric
turbine-generators deliver,

combined, 180,000 horsepower to
the propellers—enough to drive the
ship at 33 knots (39 miles an hour)
—enough to furnish light and power
for a city of half a million
people.
The design and construction of the
electric equipment for the U.S. S.
Saratoga and the U.S.S. Lexington,
to which college-trained men contributed in great measure,
exemplify the part General
Electric plays in promoting
the welfare of the nation.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 7, 1928

4

Glee Club to Sing
At Weekly Assembly
One of the most interesting fea
tures of the assembly this week will
be the exhibition of a newly invented musical instrument through
the courtesy of the local branch of
the General Electric Company. The
entire program will be of a musical
nature and will be conducted by the
Musical Club. It is hoped that the
success of the program will arouse
interest in the club's annual Home
Concert on February 24.
The Glee Club ensemble will sing
three numbers—the Hopkins Ode,
the Hopkins Medley, and 0 lilt's.sHanna. There will also be songs
by the Glee Club Quartet and both
instrumental and vocal solos.
It is advisable that freshmen and
sophomores attend this assembly, as
the rolls of their classes will be
called.
At the assembly of February 23,
the Junior and Senior debating
teams will clash on the subject of
foreign intervention in Nicaragua.
The third year debaters will argue
against intervention while the seniors will defend the present American policy.

Many to Attend

This dinner is the conception of
the Cornell Alumni who desire to
honor one of their members, following what has been one of the
most successful seasons Hopkins
has ever had in sports. However,
the affair will not be closed to other
than Cornell men. Members of the
Hopkins Varsity Club, Omicron
Delta Kappa, and the '27 Football
Team have been invited and are expected to attend. In addition to
these groups many other Hopkins
Alumni who have been interested
in the career of Dr. Van Orman,
are to be invited. Altogether, about
200 persons are expected to attend.
Among the prominent people who
have accepted invitations to be present are Congressman Daniel A.
Reed, of New York; Allen Gould,
General Sports Editor of the Associated Press; Colonel J. Beacham,
head of the R. 0. T. C. at Cornell;
and Robertson Griswold of the J.
H. U.
Dr. Van Orman graduated from
Cornell in 1908. While there he
played end on some of the finest
teams ever to represent the Ithaca
organization and was on the team
that won for Cornell the sobriquet
of the "Big Red Team." Selected
for a number of All-American
teams and given honorable meiltion by practically every football
writer, Van Orman was known as
a smart and courageous player,
whose tackling was deadly and
whose offensive play was on a par
with his defensive. Following
graduation Van returned to Cornell
as an end coach, and spent many
years , there in this capacity. He
was secured by the Black and Blue
in 1920.
There has been a rumor given
publicity lately ,by the local newspapers that Dr. Van Orman has
been offered the position of head
coach at Cornell and that he would
accept the offer at the expiration of
his contract at Johns Hopkins. Dr.
Van Orman denied this rumor and
it now appears as though he would
remain in charge of athletics at
Hopkins as long as varsity teams
represent the Black and Blue.

THE USELESSNESS OF ENGLISH LITERATURE
EXAMINATIONS
The inefficacy of the very great majority of college examinations as indices of what a student gains from a course has been
asserted so many times that it is almost an axiom. There are few
instructors who woudl maintain that they are capable of framing
an examination-which really does what it purports to do. Nevertheless, in the absence of any practical substitute, in large classes
particularly, every American college has its two or three examination periods a year.
The chances of giving a fair examination vary, however, in
different courses. Dr. Barnett, .for example, is known to give a
comprehensive examination which is usually a good gauge of the
student's mastery of the subject. In the subjects he teaches it
seems to be possible to do this, and moreover; to grade the students
with accuracy.
In certain other subjects, however, notably English Literature,
an examination which will really give the instructor an idea of the
student's knowledge and appreciation of the course is almost impossible. And if it is a difficult task to draw up an examination,
it is about fifty times that difficult to grade one. Is there any
man alive who believes that a professor of English Literature
can determine whether a student's work merits an 8.0 or an 8.5?
Or.does anyone even believe, truthfully, that a professor can often
tell, from the result of quizzes and examinations, the difference
between a 7.0 and an 8.0, or an 8.0 and a 9.0? Yes, he can quote
six words from a poem or a play and ask the student to identify
the quoted line as to author, work, and context; either the student knows, or does not know. Or he can ask the student, on the
other hand, what a certain poet meant in a certain one of his
sonnets; if the poor student doesn't happen to remember that particular sonnet, down goes his mark! Again, there may be a
question on what Matthew Arnold thinks about Crabbe. One
of the most misleading questions, from the point of view of the
possible satisfactoriness of the answer, is the one which asks a
student to describe, often in detail, some lyrical poem, such as an
elegy, an ode, or a love lyric. It is perfectly obvious that the
quality of the answers to most such questions depends in a large
degree upon two factors, neither of which is an accurate indication of the student's real appreciation of the literature he has
read. One is the retentiveness of the memory, and the other is
the student's relative powers of articulation.
The former is, logically, an anomaly. It is an accepted fact
that many students are capable of remembering, for two or three
days, details of a very large number of poems which they will
forget within a week after the examination. The latter objection
depends upon what is to be recognized as the purpose of literature
courses. If the purpose of a literature course be to awaken an
interest in good literature by bringing the student into contact
with it, the fact that he cannot express himself as glibly as his
classmate does not indicate tha.t his appreciation is any the less.
And even if part of the purpose 'of such courses is to develop
literary expression on the part of the student himself, making him
write down from memory the results of much cramming is hardly
the way to accomplish the end.
In the case of courses in English Literature there is a definite
alternate to an examination—the term paper. Such papers,
carefully outlined by the instructor so as to cover fully the scope
of the semester's work, would serve a far better purpose than an
examination for which a student stuffs his head for a week in
advance. The writing of a comprehensive paper would not only
make the student much more familiar wth the literature itself, but
would develop the student's powers of expression. He will remember much more as the result of this work than he will from having
studied for an examination.
Few people will deny the validity of this argument. This is no
essay written for the purpose of filling space: we believe that
examinations in English Literature are useless and unfair. We
believe that if the English Department should abolish examinations
at the end of the next semester and substitute in their place comprehensive term papers written under the general supervision of
the instructors, the men taking literature courses will derive far
greater benefit from those courses. Why not give the scheme a
try?

A Marvel of National Defense
From this 23'-acre deck, Uncle
Sam's battle planes can now leap
into action—sure of a landing
place on their return, though a
thousand miles from shore.
This marvel of national defense
was accomplished and duplicated
—when the airplane carrier, U.S.S.
Saratoga, and her sister ship, U.S.S.
Lexington, were completely
electrified.
In each, four General Electric
turbine-generators deliver,

combined, 180,000 horsepower to
the propellers—enough to drive the
ship at 33 knots (39 miles an hour)
—enough to furnish light and power
for a city of half a million
people.
The design and construction of the
electric equipment for the U.S. S.
Saratoga and the U.S.S. Lexington,
to which college-trained men contributed in great measure,
exemplify the part General
Electric plays in promoting
the welfare of the nation.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 7, 1928

4

Glee Club to Sing
At Weekly Assembly
One of the most interesting fea
tures of the assembly this week will
be the exhibition of a newly invented musical instrument through
the courtesy of the local branch of
the General Electric Company. The
entire program will be of a musical
nature and will be conducted by the
Musical Club. It is hoped that the
success of the program will arouse
interest in the club's annual Home
Concert on February 24.
The Glee Club ensemble will sing
three numbers—the Hopkins Ode,
the Hopkins Medley, and 0 lilt's.sHanna. There will also be songs
by the Glee Club Quartet and both
instrumental and vocal solos.
It is advisable that freshmen and
sophomores attend this assembly, as
the rolls of their classes will be
called.
At the assembly of February 23,
the Junior and Senior debating
teams will clash on the subject of
foreign intervention in Nicaragua.
The third year debaters will argue
against intervention while the seniors will defend the present American policy.

Where "good enough" isn't
In producing •a college play everything depends on rehearsal. Every part must dovetail
into every other part. And only endless hours
of hard work can result in a smooth running
production.
Nor is a college play any different in this respect from a great industrial enterprise. Every
day in the Western Electric shops men cooperate
unceasingly in the effort to insure smooth running
in the machinery of producing the nation's telephone equipment — a job unmatched in complexity in the whole field of industry.
The actors in the Western Electric drama are
setting new standards for themselves, developing
broader responsibilities as they develop new and
better manufacturing methods.

Many to Attend

This dinner is the conception of
the Cornell Alumni who desire to
honor one of their members, following what has been one of the
most successful seasons Hopkins
has ever had in sports. However,
the affair will not be closed to other
than Cornell men. Members of the
Hopkins Varsity Club, Omicron
Delta Kappa, and the '27 Football
Team have been invited and are expected to attend. In addition to
these groups many other Hopkins
Alumni who have been interested
in the career of Dr. Van Orman,
are to be invited. Altogether, about
200 persons are expected to attend.
Among the prominent people who
have accepted invitations to be present are Congressman Daniel A.
Reed, of New York; Allen Gould,
General Sports Editor of the Associated Press; Colonel J. Beacham,
head of the R. 0. T. C. at Cornell;
and Robertson Griswold of the J.
H. U.
Dr. Van Orman graduated from
Cornell in 1908. While there he
played end on some of the finest
teams ever to represent the Ithaca
organization and was on the team
that won for Cornell the sobriquet
of the "Big Red Team." Selected
for a number of All-American
teams and given honorable meiltion by practically every football
writer, Van Orman was known as
a smart and courageous player,
whose tackling was deadly and
whose offensive play was on a par
with his defensive. Following
graduation Van returned to Cornell
as an end coach, and spent many
years , there in this capacity. He
was secured by the Black and Blue
in 1920.
There has been a rumor given
publicity lately ,by the local newspapers that Dr. Van Orman has
been offered the position of head
coach at Cornell and that he would
accept the offer at the expiration of
his contract at Johns Hopkins. Dr.
Van Orman denied this rumor and
it now appears as though he would
remain in charge of athletics at
Hopkins as long as varsity teams
represent the Black and Blue.
